image_1.description: The Piketon Uranium Enrichment Facility, located in an Appalachian valley in Ohio, is a European-owned plant that houses uranium enrichment centrifuges. It is described as a cavernous, Pentagon-size facility with thousands of empty holes on the bare concrete floor, out of which only 16 are currently housing the centrifuges that enrich uranium. This facility is significant in the context of the United States' reliance on nuclear power and its predicament with Russia regarding enriched uranium supplies.

image_1.merged_entity_name: American Companies' Uranium Payments to Russia
image_1.description: American companies are paying around $1 billion a year to Russia's state-owned nuclear agency, Rosatom, for enriched uranium that generates more than half of the United States' emissions-free energy. This significant financial flow continues despite the ongoing war in Ukraine and efforts by U.S. allies to sever economic ties with Moscow. The enriched uranium payments are made to subsidiaries of Rosatom, which is closely intertwined with Russia's military apparatus.

image_2.description: Max Bearak is the author of the article discussing the uranium enrichment and its implications on the war in Ukraine and America's energy transition. He is depicted as a man with glasses, wearing a denim shirt, and holding two telephone receivers to his ears.

The European-owned plant in Ohio, also known as the uranium enrichment facility, is involved in uranium enrichment but currently yields much less than the U.S. nuclear industry needs. It is situated in Piketon, within the Appalachian valley.

The New York Times Company is the publisher of the newspaper, providing news and articles on various topics, including the predicament of the United States relying on Russian uranium for its nuclear power plants.

The uranium enrichment facility, compared in size to the Pentagon, is a cavernous, Pentagon-size facility nestled in an Appalachian valley, where thousands of empty holes line the bare concrete floor, with only 16 housing the centrifuges that enrich uranium.

Russia's state-owned nuclear agency, Rosatom, is the entity to which American companies pay around $1 billion a year for enriched uranium, which generates more than half of the United States’ emissions-free energy. Rosatom is closely intertwined with Russia’s military apparatus.

image_3.description: Periods of economic downturn indicated on a line graph by shaded areas labeled 'RECESSIONS', showing the percentage of something over time from 2000 to 2020.
A label on the graph indicating a period where there was no significant change in the measured percentage.

image_4.description: A mixture of organic waste materials including food scraps, leaves, and other biodegradable items being sorted for composting, which is part of South Korea's national program to cut emissions and process its food waste into fuel, feed, and fertilizer.

image_6.description: A group of people participating in a protest in Iran, holding orange and black flags and various signs, with a building in the background.
Indirect talks between the United States and Iran occurred this spring in the Gulf Arab state of Oman, reflecting a resumption of diplomacy.

image_7.description: A renowned luxury jewelry brand known for its high-quality and exquisite diamond jewelry, including GRAFF DIAMOND RING (YELLOW) and GRAFF DIAMOND RING (WHITE).
